review.title: Reasoning in Non-Probabilistic Uncertainty: Logic Programming and Neural-Symbolic Computing as Examples
review.abstract: This article aims to achieve two goals: to show that probability is not the only way of dealing with uncertainty (and even more, that there are kinds of uncertainty which are for principled reasons not addressable with probabilistic means); and to provide evidence that logic-based methods can well support reasoning with uncertainty. For the latter claim, two paradigmatic examples are presented: Logic Programming with Kleene semantics for modelling reasoning from information in a discourse, to an interpretation of the state of affairs of the intended model, and a neural-symbolic implementation of Input/Output logic for dealing with uncertainty in dynamic normative contexts.

sections.heading: 3.1 Neural-Symbolic Systems
sections.text: The main purpose of neural-symbolic integration is to bridge the gap between symbolic and sub-symbolic representations. To this end, neural-symbolic systems are brought together to avoid their disadvantages. For our present purposes, we are particularly interested in three successive steps: the representation of the norms that formally and solidly govern a normative system in an ANN; the use of the network to achieve efficient parallel computations; and finally, the exploitation of the instantial learning capacities of ANNs to adapt the norms in the system, which should lead to a normative system capable of effectively integrating argumentation and learning capacities. In what follows, we present the basic concepts of ANNs and neural symbolic systems used in this article, with an emphasis on expanding connectionist learning and logical programming (CILP).

metadata.abstractText: This article aims to achieve two goals: to show that probability is not the only way of dealing with uncertainty (and even more, that there are kinds of uncertainty which are for principled reasons not addressable with probabilistic means); and to provide evidence that logicbased methods can well support reasoning with uncertainty. For the latter claim, two paradigmatic examples are presented: Logic Programming with Kleene semantics for modelling reasoning from information in a discourse, to an interpretation of the state of affairs of the intended model, and a neural-symbolic implementation of Input/Output logic for dealing with uncertainty in dynamic normative contexts.
